context: Internationally, Victoria took a keen interest in the <a15_0>improvement of relations between <a0_0><a5_0><b20_0>France and Britain<b20_0/><a15_0/><a5_0/><a0_0/>. She made and hosted several visits between the British royal family and the <a6_0><a14_0>House of Orleans<a14_0/><a6_0/>, who were related <a1_0><b21_0>by marriage through the Coburgs<b21_0/><a1_0/>. In 1843 and 1845, she and Albert stayed with <a2_0><a7_0><b22_0>King Louis Philippe I<b22_0/><a7_0/><a2_0/> at château d'Eu in Normandy; she was the first British or English monarch to visit a French one since the meeting of Henry VIII of England and Francis I of France on the Field of the Cloth of Gold in 1520. When <a8_0><a10_0>Louis Philippe<a10_0/><a8_0/> made a reciprocal trip in <a3_0><b23_0>1844<b23_0/><a3_0/>, he became the first French king to visit a British sovereign. Louis Philippe was deposed in the revolutions of <a16_0>1848<a16_0/>, and <a11_0>fled to exile in England<a11_0/>. At the height of a revolutionary scare in the United Kingdom in April 1848, Victoria and her family left London for the greater safety of <a12_0><a17_0>Osborne House<a12_0/>, a private estate on the Isle of Wight<a17_0/> that they had purchased in <a18_0>1845<a18_0/> and redeveloped. Demonstrations by <a19_0>Chartists and Irish nationalists<a19_0/> failed to attract widespread support, and the scare died down without any major disturbances. Victoria's first visit to <a13_0>Ireland<a13_0/> in <a4_0><a9_0><b24_0>1849<b24_0/><a9_0/><a4_0/> was a public relations success, but it had no lasting impact or effect on the growth of Irish nationalism.
